content:
Burnley Borough Council's 2026/27 budget is expected to be presented to the Executive on 25 February 2026 and approved by Full Council on 3 March 2026. With a business rates reset stripping £2.2 million from the council's income and a 6% reduction in government support over the next three years, this may be one of the most challenging budgets in the council's history - and potentially one of its last, given Local Government Reorganisation.

The Budget Gap

The council's budget forecast published in March 2025 predicted a shortfall of £800,000 for 2026/27. Following updated forecasts in September 2025, this was revised down to £181,000. The council has stated plans are in place to close the remaining gap.

The reduction from £800,000 to £181,000 is welcome - but the underlying pressures remain significant.

The Business Rates Reset: £2.2 Million Lost

From April 2026, the Government is resetting the business rates retention system nationally. For Burnley, this means the loss of approximately £2.2 million per year in accumulated business rates growth that the council had previously been able to retain.

To put this in context: the council's total revenue budget for 2025/26 was £18.7 million. Losing £2.2 million represents an 11.8% income reduction from a single policy change.

Over the period 2026 to 2029, the council faces an overall reduction of approximately 6% in government support - around £1.3 million per year, phased in gradually. While transitional protections exist (100% income protection where the pre/post-reform difference is 15% or less), the direction of travel is clear: Burnley will have less money.

How 2026/27 Compares to 2025/26

The 2025/26 revenue budget was £18.721 million, down from £18.987 million in 2024/25. Key figures:

Funding Source 2024/25 2025/26 Change
Business Rate Retention £8,054k £6,409k -£1,645k
Revenue Support Grant £2,175k £2,232k +£57k
Council Tax Requirement £8,055k £8,306k +£251k
New Homes Bonus £134k £239k +£105k

The biggest shift is the £1.6 million drop in business rate retention - a trend that will accelerate dramatically in 2026/27 with the full reset.

Council Tax: What to Expect

The council tax referendum principle for shire district councils for 2026/27 is up to 3% or £5, whichever is higher.

In 2025/26, Burnley chose a 2.0% increase (below the maximum 3%), taking the Band D Burnley element to £344.58. Along with Ribble Valley, Burnley was the only council in Lancashire not to raise council tax to the maximum - described as the first time in over a decade such a decision had been made.

It remains to be seen whether the council will maintain this below-maximum approach for 2026/27, given the significant budget pressures from the business rates reset.

For context, the total Band D council tax bill in 2025/26 was £2,447.50 - a 4.6% increase on the previous year. The Burnley Borough Council element represents just 14% of the total bill, with Lancashire County Council accounting for 70.7%.

Fees, Charges, and Savings

A report presented to councillors in January 2026 recommends a 2% increase to most council fees and charges from 1 April 2026 - significantly below the CPI inflation rate of 3.2%. Garden waste subscriptions and car parking charges are proposed to be frozen.

For 2025/26, the council identified ongoing revenue budget savings of £328,000. Savings have been described as focused on efficiency measures rather than direct frontline service cuts.

The National Picture

The Provisional Local Government Finance Settlement, published 17 December 2025, is the first multi-year settlement in a decade, covering 2026/27 to 2028/29. Key points:

  • National Core Spending Power: £77.7 billion for 2026/27 (up from £68.5bn in 2024/25)
  • Core Spending Power increases nationally: 5.7% in 2026/27, 4.3% in 2027/28, 4.4% in 2028/29
  • The business rates retention system is being fully reset for the first time
  • The Fair Funding Review is being implemented - the first reassessment of relative needs since 2013
  • 67-70% of shire district councils are expected to see real-terms funding fall over the three-year period

Lancashire's overall allocation shows a headline increase - Burnley's MP Oliver Ryan welcomed a "major funding boost" - but the headline figures mask the fact that around 80% of local services funding in Burnley comes from Lancashire County Council, not the borough council. The borough council's own income is under significant pressure.

The LGR Shadow

This budget is being set against the backdrop of Local Government Reorganisation. Burnley Borough Council may cease to exist by 31 March 2028. The statutory consultation on LGR options in Lancashire runs until 26 March 2026.

This context affects every budget decision: how much to invest in capital projects, how to manage reserves, whether to enter long-term contracts, and whether to maintain spending on services that a successor authority may restructure.

The council holds £25.8 million in earmarked reserves and £1.4 million in general fund reserves. How these are managed over the remaining life of the council will be a critical question.

What to Watch For

When the budget is published (expected at the Executive meeting on 25 February 2026), key questions include:

  • Council tax: Will Burnley again keep the increase below the maximum referendum threshold?
  • Business rates impact: How will the £2.2 million income loss be absorbed?
  • Reserves: Will reserves be drawn down to bridge the gap, or will services face cuts?
  • Liberata contract: The major outsourcing contract expires in 2026 - what comes next?
  • Capital investment: Will the council continue investing, or scale back given the uncertain future?
  • LGR costs: How much is being set aside for the transition to a new unitary authority?

The budget papers will be published on the council's ModernGov portal when available. We will update this analysis once the full budget is published.

Sources: Burnley Borough Council Budget Book 2025-26; Burnley Council press releases; Provisional Local Government Finance Settlement 2026-29; Burnley Express; Council tax statutory financial information 2025/26.
